metadata.title: Fabrication of superhydrophobic reduced-graphene oxide/nickel coating with mechanical durability, self-cleaning and anticorrosion performance

sections.text:
Nano Materials Science xxx (xxxx) xxx
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Nano Materials Science
journal homepage: www.keaipublishing.com/cn/journals/nano-materials-science/
Fabrication of superhydrophobic reduced-graphene oxide/nickel coating with mechanical durability, self-cleaning and anticorrosion performance
Zengguo Bai, Bin Zhang *
Key Laboratory for Anisotropy and Texture of Materials, Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, 3-11 Wenhua Road, Shenyang, 110819, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: rGO/Ni composite coating Electrodeposition Superhydrophobic Mechanical abrasion Anticorrosion
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: zhangb@atm.neu.edu.cn (B. Zha
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoms.2019.05.001 Received 10 March 2019; Accepted 25 April 2019 Available online xxxx 2589-9651/© 2019 Chongqing University. Product (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).
Please cite this article as: Z. Bai, B. Zhang, Fab cleaning and anticorrosion performance, Nan
A B S T R A C T
There is a great challenge to fabricate superhydrophobic coating with excellent mechanical durability and corrosion resistance. Inspired by the pinecone-shaped structure, a novel reduced-graphene oxide (rGO)/Ni composite coating with pinecone-like micro/nanostructures was fabricated successfully on a stainless steel substrate using a simple electrodeposition method combining Ni pre-deposition and an elevated current assistant approach. The results show that the coating is of self-cleaning and superhydrophicity with a water contact angle (CA) of 162.7 0.8 and a sliding angle (SA) of 2.5 1.0 . Importantly, the coating still maintains the excellent self-cleaning and superhydrophicity, water CA of 155.8 1.2 and SA of 5.9 1.2 , even after 100-cycle mechanical abrasion. Meanwhile, the coating also exhibits good anticorrosion performance in 3.5 wt% NaCl solution, with 99.98% inhibition efficiency. The simple fabrication method may provide a cost-effective way to prepare mechanically durable, anticorrosive, self-cleaning and superhydrophobic coatings on metal substrates.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Superhydrophobic surfaces with water contact angles (CA)> 150 , and sliding angles (SA)< 10 have attracted more and more attention due to their numerous potential applications including anti-icing [1,2], self-cleaning [3–5], oil-water separation [6], anticorrosion [7] and drag reduction [8]. Inspired by the “lotus effect”, artificial superhydrophobic materials have been successfully prepared with enough surface roughness and low surface energy. Water droplets could become nearly spherical shapes due to the existence of surface tension and repulsive force, collecting and removing the contaminants when they bounce and roll off the superhydrophobic surfaces. However, the most troubling issue of the as-fabricated superhydrophobic surfaces is the adhesion to the substrates and the durability of the micro/nanostructures [9–12].
To date, various efforts have been made to fabricate bio-inspired superhydrophobic surfaces, such as sol-gel [13], 3D printing [14–16], chemical etching [17], chemical vapor deposition [18], electro-spinning [19] and self-assembly [20,21]. Most of these methods are complex and time-consuming, limiting their large-scale industrial applications. In contrast, electrodeposition [22–28] is a simple, controllable, and economical method. Esmailzadeh et al. [29] reported that a thin superhydrophobic nickel layer with water CA of 155 and roughness (Ra) of
ng).
ion and hosting by Elsevier B.V. o
rication of superhydrophobic r o Materials Science , https://d
93 nm 8 nm was electrodeposited on a copper substrate, consisting of micro-cones deposited at a low current density (CD) and nano-cones deposited on the surfaces of the micro-cones after the CD was enhanced. Besides, to further increase surface roughness of the coatings [30], various additives have been selected and mixed in the electrolyte as an assistant to deposit hierarchical micro/nanostructures on surfaces [31–35]. Reduced graphene oxide (rGO) is a suitable additive candidate to fabricate superhydrophobic materials [36–39] not only due to the hydrophobicity itself but to its large specific surface area, abrasion resistance and excellent conductivity. Ding et al. [37] have constructed a superhydrophobic rGO/nickel composite coating on a mild steel substrate. Unfortunately, the substrate could not be covered completely by the rGO/nickel composite particles though the water CA achieved 160.4 1.5 after the electrodeposition process at a lower constant CD. Furthermore, biological poison fluorine-based materials [6,8,10], such as fluoroalkylsilane (FAS), are utilized to achieve a low-energy surface in many materials, which leads to environmental pollution. Therefore, environmentally friendly, cost-effective stearic acid (STA) [34] or myristic acid [22] with similar effects have been applied to improve the superhydrophobicity of coating.
In this paper, a simple, environmentally friendly and cost-effective method combining Ni pre-deposition (NPD) and an elevated current
n behalf of KeAi. This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license
educed-graphene oxide/nickel coating with mechanical durability, selfoi.org/10.1016/j.nanoms.2019.05.001
assistant (ECA) electrodeposition approach was designed to fabricate a rough enough surface with an abrasion resistant pinecone-inspired hierarchical micro/nano structures. After the NPD approach, the stainless steel (SS) substrate was covered completely by a fresh and thin nickel layer, followed by a deposition of stacked rGO/Ni micro/nanoparticles on the NPD layer to enhance the surface roughness through a lower CD, and then an ECA process was employed to construct a pinecone-like hierarchical micro/nano rGO/Ni composite surface. At last, STA was selected to modify the as-deposited composite coating further to improve the superhydrophobicity. The formation mechanism of the special pinecone-like hierarchical micro/nanostructure was investigated, and mechanical stability, self-cleaning and anticorrosion performance of the as-fabricated samples were characterized and evaluated.

sections.heading: 2. Fabrication and characterization of superhydrophobic coating
2.1. Pretreatment of substrates
sections.text: A 304 SS plate was cut into small pieces with dimensions of 20mm 25mm 2mm. All the SS pieces, used as cathode substrates, were mechanically polished by silicon carbide (SiC) sandpapers, and then immersed into the ultrasonic cleaning solutions in the sequence of acetone, ethanol and deionized (DI) water for each 10min, respectively. A piece of nickel plate (99.99%) was used as the anode plate after being ultrasonic cleaned in DI water for 10min.

sections.heading: 2.2. Ni pre-deposition
sections.text: A thin layer of nickel was electrodeposited on the substrate by using a direct current supply power with CD of 50mA cm 2 for 2min at 25 C. The NPD solution consisted of 200 g L 1 NiCl2⋅6H2O and 1.5mol⋅ L 1 hydrochloric acid.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrodeposition of rGO/Ni composite layer
sections.text: A sample with pre-deposited Ni layer was rinsed with DI water first, and then immediately immersed in an electrolyte with pH of 4.5–5.0, composing of 200 g L 1 NiCl2⋅6H2O, 30 g L 1 orthoboric acid, 30 g L 1 potassium chloride, 0.1 g L 1 sodium dodecyl benzene sulfonate and 0.1 g L 1 rGO (purchased from Suzhou Tanfeng Science and Technology Co., Ltd). The electrolyte was fully stirred for 24 h in advance, and then ultrasonically treated for 30min to form a stable and uniform suspension. On top of the NPD layer, rGO/Ni composite particles were deposited at a lower CD of 20mA cm 2 for 5min and 10min, respectively, at 60 C under magnetic stirring first, and the samples were named as GN5 and GN10, respectively. Continuously, Sample GN10 was deposited for another 2min at an elevated CD of 50mA cm 2 (ECA approach), being renamed as GNE. Finally, all the samples were rinsed in DI water and ethanol solution, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.4. Fabrication of STA-rGO/Ni superhydrophobic coating
sections.text: The as-deposited samples GN10 and GNE were incubated for 30min in an ethanol solution with 0.1 mol L 1 STA, followed by washing in ethanol and then dried in a vacuum oven at 80 C for 1 h. The STAtreated samples were named as S-GN10 and S-GNE, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.5. Characterization of microstructures
sections.text: Surface morphology of the coatings was observed through a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, LEO Supra 35). Chemical composition of the coatings was analyzed by an X-ray photoelectron spectroscope (XPS, Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi). Surface roughness (Ra) was measured by using a laser confocal scanning microscope (LCSM, Olympus OLS 4000).

sections.heading: 2.6. Examination of superhydrophobicity, mechanical stability and anticorrosion performance
sections.text: Water CAs and SAs of the samples were recorded with ~3 μL water droplets by using an optical contact angle meter (JCY-2, Fangrui). The asfabricated coating was faced down to a 400-grit SiC sandpaper, and then a 100 g weight was placed on the back of the sample for detecting mechanical stability of the coating and counting the abrasion cycles [40]. The superhydrophobic surface, facing to the sandpaper, was first moved for 10 cm to the right along the ruler at a constant speed, and then rotated by 90 and moved to the left along the ruler for 10 cm. This process was defined as one abrasion cycle. Corrosion resistance of the coatings was examined by using an electrochemical workstation (Autolab M204, Metrohm). A three-electrode cell with a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference, a platinum electrode as the counter, and the samples with exposed area of 1 cm2 as the working electrode was immersed in 3.5 wt% NaCl solution (pH~5.9) for 30min to obtain a stable open circuit potential. The potentiodynamic polarization curves were measured at a sweep rate of 10mV/s, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) curves were measured with a sinusoidal perturbation signal of 5 mV amplitude and a frequency ranging from 10 2 Hz–105 Hz.

sections.heading: 3.1. Microstructures of coatings
sections.text:
Fig. 1a shows an SEM image of the rGO/Ni surface coating fabricated through the ECA approach. It is clear that a dense composite coating with thickness of ~200 μm has formed on the Ni pre-deposited SS substrate (Fig. 1b). Fig. 1c presents the rGO/Ni composite coating deposited layer by layer after 5min deposition at the lower constant CD of 20mA cm 2. Micron-sized rGO sheets (see the inset in Fig. 1c) provided more nucleation sites for the subsequent nickel deposition and generated more protrusions on the fresh NPD surface. As time went by, these rGO sheets were buried gradually by new deposited nickel and could be hardly
observed. After 10min deposition, the stacked rGO/Ni composite micro/ nanoparticles formed, and nickel needles with an average diameter of ~300 nm distributed homogeneously on both the as-deposited rGO sheet surfaces and the bare areas without rGO sheets to form a rough surface of the GN10 sample, as shown in Fig. 1d. Compared with that of Sample GN10, a GNE coating shown in Fig. 1e reveals a pinecone-like hierarchical micro/nano stacking morphology, fabricated through the ECA approach. With increasing CD, most of the nickel crystals were passivated due to the enhancement of effect of cathodic polarization [29,41]. Then pinecone-like sedimentary rGO/Ni composite coating was formed (Fig. 1e) and its zoomed in image was shown in Fig. 1f.
Three-dimensional LSCM images of GN10 and GNE coatings are shown in Fig. 2a and b, respectively. The GNE coating with Ra¼ 67.3 1.0 μm (Fig. 2b) is much rougher than the GN10 one (Ra ¼ 44.8 7.1 μm, as shown in Fig. 2a) due to the special stacking morphology, pinecone-like hierarchical micro/nanostructures.

sections.heading: 3.2. Chemical composition of coatings
sections.text:
XPS spectra of the S-GNE sample are shown in Fig. 3. Elements of Ni, O and C are clearly observed in the XPS spectra (Fig. 3a), and the atomic percentage of each element is 70.61 C%, 4.27 O%, and 5.12 Ni%, respectively. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum shown in Fig. 3b was deconvoluted into five peaks at 852.2 eV, 853.9 eV, 855.6 eV, 856.6 eV, and 861.0 eV. The peak developed at the binding energy 852.2 eV is ascribed to Ni0, metallic Ni [42,43], whereas features appear at 855.6 eV and 856.6 eV are ascribed to NiOOH (Ni3þ states), and Ni(OH)2, respectively [43,44]. Peaks at 853.9 eV and 861.0 eV correspond to NiO [43]. It was inevitable that a little bit Ni would transform into oxidation states in an open experiment environment [45]. Fig. 3c depicts the O 1s spectrum that was deconvoluted clearly into five peaks at 529.5 eV, 530.5 eV, 531.5 eV, 532.3 eV and 533.8 eV, respectively. The peak at 529.5 eV is attributed to O2 (Ni–O) [46]. The peaks at 530.5 eV and 531.5 eV are resulted from
the Ni3þ species (NiOOH) [47] and Ni2þ species (Ni(OH)2) [48,49], respectively. The peaks at 532.3 eV and 533.8 eV correspond to O2 ions in carboxylate (–COO–) group [50] and H2O [46]. In Fig. 3d, C 1s deconvolution spectrum exhibits four different peaks centered at 284.6 eV, 285.2 eV, 286.9 eV and 288.5 eV, corresponding to C–C/C–C (rGO/STA), C–H, C–O (rGO), and O–C–O (STA) groups [51,52], respectively. This indicates that rGO and a long-chain aliphatic group including –COO– bond are formed in the rGO/Ni composite coating because –OH groups (NiO–OH/Ni–OH) on nickel surfaces have reacted with –COOH groups of STA and formed a stable covalent bond compound, which further confirms a successful STA modification.

sections.heading: 3.3. Superhydrophobicity of coatings
sections.text:
Fig. 4 presents water CAs and SAs of the as-fabricated NPD, S-GN10 and S-GNE samples. After 10min deposition at lower CD of 20mA cm 2, the water CA and SA of the S-GN10 sample are 158.3 1.0 and 4.6 1.1 , respectively. Through the ECA process, the S-GNE coating with pinecone-like hierarchical micro/nanostructures reached CA of 162.7 0.8 , and the SA decreased down to 2.5 1.0 . It was the composite micro/nanostructure formed by Ni pinecones located at the surfaces of the rGO sheets, which provided sufficient “air pockets”, thus enabled water droplets to bounce and roll off immediately. This is consistent with Cassie-Baxter model [53] expressed by,
cosθr ¼ f1cosθ0 þ f2 (1)
where θr and θ0 are the CAs of the S-GNE and NPD (102.4 1.3 , as shown in Fig. 4a) samples, respectively; f1 and f2 (f1þf2¼ 1) represent the area fraction of the solid component and the air in contact with water, respectively. Therefore, f1 is 5.97% for the S-GNE coating, which means 94.03% area of the coating was filled with air. The trapped air may serve as air cushions, providing a resistance to the penetration of water droplets to the S-GNE coating [54].

sections.heading: 3.4. Mechanical durability of coatings
sections.text:
A variation of water CAs and SAs of the S-GNE samples as a function of mechanical abrasion cycles, and the comparison with reports in literature are shown in Fig. 5a. Obviously, the CA of the S-GNE coating after 100-cycle mechanical abrasion changed from 162.7 0.8 –155.8 1.2 and the SA transformed from 3.5 1.0 –5.9 1.2 , still maintaining great water-repellant properties. Fig. 5b presents an SEM image of the S-GNE coating surface subjected to 100-cycle mechanical abrasion, in which almost undamaged rGO/Ni composite particles can still be observed. In comparison, see Fig. 5a, the superhydrophobic PDMS/silica coating [55] and CNC/silica composite coating [56] had already lost their superhydrophobicity after ~45 and 51-cycle mechanical abrasion, respectively, and the mesh/Cu/PDMS films [57] lost after 100-cycle abrasion. Although the coatings of PDMS/silica [58], FAS-TiO2/Zn [59], and rGO/Ni [37] still maintained superhydrophobicity, they only subjected to 20, 50, and 60-cycle mechanical abrasion, respectively. The results indicate that the present S-GNE coatings with rough enough and stabilized pinecone-like micro/nanostructure have the better resistance to repeatedly mechanical abrasion, maintaining excellent superhydrophobicity after much more cycles of sandpaper abrasion than other coatings reported in literature. It was micro-sized rGO that not only providing enough roughness but excellent mechanical strength and toughness as well for the composite coating.
A schematic illustration of an S-GNE coating under cyclic sandpaper abrasion is shown in Fig. 5c. The order of numbers in Fig. 5b and c indicate the sequence of the worn out layer with increasing mechanical abrasion cycles. Surprisingly, the abraded S-GNE surface still have undamaged pinecone-like microstructure after 100-cycle sandpaper abrasion. It was the pinecone-like stacking morphology of the S-GNE coating
Fig. 3. XPS spectra of S-GNE coating (a) survey, (b) Ni 2p, (c) O 1s and (d) C 1s.
obtained by using the ECA electrodeposition process, which enables the coating to possess a better mechanical durability.

sections.heading: 3.5. Self-cleaning performance of coatings
sections.text:
To evaluate self-cleaning performance of the coatings, graphite powders were employed as contaminants and spread on the S-GNE surfaces (Fig. 6a). Apparently, the graphite powders were carried away completely by the water droplets. The lower surface adhesion allowed the water droplets to roll easily on the superhydrophobic coating surface, and take the contaminants away even without tilting surface. It was the rGO sheets adsorbed on the NPD surface during deposition that increasing nucleation sites for reduction of Ni ions [60], which results in forming an enough roughness composite coating. Therefore, the as-prepared S-GNE composite coating has a higher CA (162.7 0.8 ) than the superhydrophobic Zn coating [61] (155.29 ), which also fabricated by ECA process. The excellent superhydrophobicity of as-prepared composite coating contributes to the enhancement of self-cleaning ability. Fig. 6b schematically illustrates the self-cleaning process of the present coating surface. The pollutants lie flat on a pinecone-like S-GNE surface. A water droplet falls from a dropper and is compressed and deformed to be ellipsoidal first due to its gravity, which result in reaching the maximum contact area with the pollutants. Then, the low surface adhesion of the superhydrophobic coating provides a contact reaction-force to the water droplet, helping the water droplet bounce from the surface with the contaminants sticking on it. At last, the water droplet rolls off and takes the pollutants away smoothly. Amazingly, after 100-cycle sandpaper abrasion, the scratched S-GNE surfaces still exhibited excellent self-cleaning performance (Fig. 6c). It was the pinecone-like stacking morphology of the S-GNE coating that enables the
Fig. 5. (a) Water CAs and SAs of S-GNE coatings as a function of mechanical abrasion cycles, and comparison with reports in literature; (b) SEM image of S-GNE coating after 100th sandpaper abrasion cycles; (c) Schematic illustration of S-GNE coating after sandpaper cyclic abrasion.
Fig. 6. (a) Self-cleaning performance of S-GNE coatings contaminated by graphite powders; (b) Schematic illustration of self-cleaning process demonstrated on a surface layer of S-GNE coating; (c) Self-cleaning performance of 100-cycle sandpaper abraded S-GNE coatings contaminated by graphite powder.
abraded surfaces to possess special superhydrophobic and self-cleaning properties.

sections.heading: 3.6. Electrochemical corrosion behavior of coatings
sections.text: We use Tafel polarization curves (Fig. 7a) to investigate the protective performance of the superhydrophobic S-GNE coating, in which an SS substrate is compared with an S-GNE sample after being immersed in 3.5 wt% NaCl solution for 36 h at 25 C. Corrosion potential (Ecorr), current density (Icorr) and corrosion rate (υcorr) were calculated according to the linear extrapolation of the Tafel polarization curves (Table 1). Polarization resistances (Rp) were calculated according to Stern-Geary equation below [62],

sections.heading: Rp ¼ babc2:303ðba þ bcÞIcorr (2)
sections.text:
where ba and bc are the anodic and cathodic Tafel slopes (ΔE/ΔlogI), respectively.
As shown in Fig. 7a, Ecorr and Icorr of the S-GNE coating moving toward the lower right corner of the polarization curves indicates that the sample possesses better corrosion resistance due to a higher Ecorr and a much lower Icorr [38], 0.321 V more positive and 5.418 10 5 A⋅cm 2 lower than the bare SS substrate. In addition, the S-GNE sample has a much higher Rp (8.448 105Ω ⋅cm2), which is 5.39 103 times as high as that of the bare SS substrate, and a much lower υcorr (1.26 10 4 mm⋅a 1), suggesting its better anticorrosion performance. Fig. 7b shows EIS plots of bare SS substrate and S-GNE coatings. Compared with bare SS substrate, the S-GNE coating with a large arc radius indicates that the superhydrophobic micro/nano rGO/Ni coatings have excellent electrochemical corrosion-resistance and strong barrier ability against corrosive liquids.
The corrosion inhibition efficiency (η) of the coated samples was estimated by Ref. [63].
η¼ ½IBare SS Icoated SS IBare SS 100% (3)
where I is the corrosion current density. η of the S-GNE sample was estimated to be 99.98%, being higher than that of other reported coatings [64–67], as shown in Table 1. This indicates that the superhydrophobic S-GNE coating possesses excellent anticorrosion performance due to the present surface has distinctive pinecone-like rough enough microstructure. Fig. 7c depicts the anticorrosion mechanism of the superhydrophobic S-GNE coating. The air cushion with 94.03% area constructed by the pinecone-like hierarchical micro/nanostructure plays an important role in preventing the chloride ions in the simulated seawater from reaching the surface of the coating. The results indicate that the as-fabricated coatings with excellent repeatedly mechanical abrasion resistance, self-cleaning, and anticorrosion performances are suitable for large-scale application on any mental substrates owing to the fresh and highly reactive NPD layers providing good adhesion between the rGO/Ni composite layers and the base substrate. This simple, environmentally friendly and cost-effective method provides a new idea for fabricating ultrarobust hierarchical micro/nano superhydrophobic coatings.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
1) A simple method combining Ni pre-deposition and an elevated current assistant process, followed by a fluorine-free stearic acid modification approach was successfully designed to fabricate a rough enough surface coating with pinecone-inspired hierarchical micro/ nanostructures. 2) The surface roughness of the S-GNE sample reached 67.3 1.0 μm, and the water CAs and SAs were 162.7 0.8 and 2.5 1.0 , respectively. The coating still maintain good self-cleaning and superhydrophobicity with the water CA of 155.8 1.2 and the SA of 5.9 1.2 even after 100-cycle sandpaper abrasion.
3) Almost 94.03% surface area of the S-GNE coating can be filled with air cushion, which enables the coating to exhibit good anticorrosion performance, and 99.98% inhibition efficiency in 3.5 wt% NaCl solution.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 51671050), and partially supported by the National Key R&D Program of China (No. 2017YFB0305800) and the Joint Founds of NSFC Liaoning (No. U1508213).

metadata.abstractText: There is a great challenge to fabricate superhydrophobic coating with excellent mechanical durability and corrosion resistance. Inspired by the pinecone-shaped structure, a novel reduced-graphene oxide (rGO)/Ni composite coating with pinecone-like micro/nanostructures was fabricated successfully on a stainless steel substrate using a simple electrodeposition method combining Ni pre-deposition and an elevated current assistant approach. The results show that the coating is of self-cleaning and superhydrophicity with a water contact angle (CA) of 162.7 0.8 and a sliding angle (SA) of 2.5 1.0 . Importantly, the coating still maintains the excellent self-cleaning and superhydrophicity, water CA of 155.8 1.2 and SA of 5.9 1.2 , even after 100-cycle mechanical abrasion. Meanwhile, the coating also exhibits good anticorrosion performance in 3.5 wt% NaCl solution, with 99.98% inhibition efficiency. The simple fabrication method may provide a cost-effective way to prepare mechanically durable, anticorrosive, self-cleaning and superhydrophobic coatings on metal substrates.
